oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Reticuloruminal disturbances in the bovine
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ivany, Jennifer M.
Rings, D. Michael
Anderson, David E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: clinical aspects
digestive system diseases
digestive tract
digestive tract motility
physiopathology
reticulum
reviews
rumen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The forestomach of the ruminant animal is a highly effective energy-producing factory which can utilize a wide variety of feedstuffs. Many complex interactions occur within the forestomachs to digest, mix, and absorb nutrients from feed. Slight alterations in forestomach balance can lead to severe alterations in function, such as hypomotility, hypermotility, bloat, acidosis, or putrefaction. It is essential to understand and be able to treat and prevent forestomach disease in cattle. Some of the most common diseases are reviewed here, possible treatments given, and the use of motility-enhancing drugs is briefly discussed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Bovine Practitioner; Vol. 36, No. 1 (2002 February); 56-64
